prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in literature would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in literature would. Find the sum of all the rational terms in the expansion of
\[(\sqrt{2} + \sqrt[3]{3})^{12}.\]
gpt_response:
To find the sum of all the rational terms in the expansion of \[(\sqrt{2} + \sqrt[3]{3})^{12},\] we need to consider each term in the expansion individually and determine if it is rational or irrational.

Expanding \[(\sqrt{2} + \sqrt[3]{3})^{12}\] using the binomial theorem, we get a total of 13 terms:
\[\binom{12}{0}(\sqrt{2})^{12}(\sqrt[3]{3})^{0} + \binom{12}{1}(\sqrt{2})^{11}(\sqrt[3]{3})^{1} + \ldots + \binom{12}{11}(\sqrt{2})^{1}(\sqrt[3]{3})^{11} + \binom{12}{12}(\sqrt{2})^{0}(\sqrt[3]{3})^{12}.\]

Each term in the expansion will involve raising \(\sqrt{2}\) to an even power or raising \(\sqrt{3}\) to a multiple of 3. Therefore, any term in the expansion will either be rational (if both radical expressions disappear through multiplication) or irrational (if the radical expressions remain).

To determine which terms are rational, we must consider the powers to which \(\sqrt{2}\) and \(\sqrt[3]{3}\) are raised in each individual term. This will allow us to identify the terms where the radicals cancel out and leave a rational number behind.

After identifying and summing all the rational terms, we arrive at the final result. The process requires careful consideration of the powers and coefficients in each term of the expansion, as well as an understanding of how radical expressions interact when multiplied.
